stream_context.summary: Kaze spent most of this bonus stream inside Blender re-working the snowy castle (Course 3) and briefly Course 4.  The big push was building a new, data-driven mirror system while chasing a stubborn lighting bug and monitoring performance under the new X3 microcode.

development_findings.summary: Implemented a new mirror actor that stores axis, range and pivot in a compact 8-byte struct, making future mirrors "the easiest system ever" to add.
development_findings.quote: Dude, this is gonna be the easiest system to add new mirrors ever.

development_findings.summary: Fixed mirror orientation bugs by inverting scale and adjusting yaw only when the mirrored axis is not Y.
Discovered an ambient-light reset bug triggered by a second light source; believes it originates from using the X2 lighting struct on emulator while X3 behaves correctly on console.
development_findings.quote: Something with the shading is really broken right now… I load x2 geo mario lights instead of x3 and the ambient seems to completely disappear.

development_findings.summary: Course 3 performance test (no room culling, no optimizations) shows ~23 FPS; with room occlusion he expects full 60 FPS on real hardware.
Identified RSP as the main bottleneck; switching from Fast3D X2 to X3 microcode raised Course 1 from 46 FPS to 60 FPS.
development_findings.quote: We found out that the bottleneck is actually the RSP … when we only improved the RSP performance in X3, that’s when it went up.

development_findings.summary: Plans a per-level memory allocator tweak to avoid collision-pool overflows caused by very large triangles.
Considering tri-strips/trifans and other RSP tricks once emulator support is dropped or Gliden64 supports them.
development_findings.quote: If I can use tri-fans and tri-strips… oh my god, I would be so happy.

development_findings.summary: Release plan: v1.0 (emulator + N64), v1.1 (bug-fix), then an N64-only branch focused on speed unless accurate plugins catch up.
Design tweaks: doors become camera blockers to guarantee 60 FPS; one narrow corridor will be merged with adjacent rooms to avoid cramped camera behaviour.
Added ‘snow demon’ enemies to pit areas to punish falls and better match the level theme.

context_findings.summary: Kaze now has a child and a full-time job, so he is streaming more to earn additional income.
context_findings.quote: I have a child now and I need more money.

context_findings.summary: Believes caring excessively about programming languages signals poor skill; sees all mainstream languages as equivalent for most tasks.
context_findings.quote: If you care at all about which programming language you use, that is a very strong indicator that you're a terrible programmer.

context_findings.summary: Foiled an elaborate spear-phishing attempt by refusing to run an .exe and cross-checking the attacker’s GitHub identity; is helping anti-scam researchers trace it.
context_findings.quote: When they wanted me to get a call… I’m not downloading an exe file ever… I think maybe we can actually figure out who tried to spear-phish me.

context_findings.summary: Work-life balance: streams occur during free days; juggling long hours between day job, family and the hack.

biobak.summary: Kaze worries Biobak will "murder" him if wall dimensions aren’t perfect squares; defers final visual polish to Biobak.
biobak.quote: Why didn’t you make it perfect squares? Fix it now while you can before the wrath of Biobak murders me.

biobak.summary: Plans to hand off the castle rooms to Biobak once basic modelling is complete so textures and lighting can be refined.

zeina.summary: Zeina (in chat) requested to see the family’s Fat Yoshi plush for the living room, hinting at casual, friendly involvement but no direct production tasks this session.

key_stories.title: The Spear-Phishing Ad Agency
key_stories.summary: A highly convincing ‘Web3 coding school’ offered to sponsor Kaze.  They provided GitHub links, referenced his videos and requested he run a meeting app.  Kaze refused to execute the file, then spotted a fake Zoom URL and contacted the real GitHub owner, an anti-scam engineer.  They are now working to identify the scammers.
key_stories.challenge: Potential sponsorship required running an unfamiliar .exe or visiting a spoofed Zoom site.
key_stories.process: Refused to run the file, verified identities, contacted the legitimate developer.
key_stories.outcome: Averted the hack and passed evidence to anti-scam professionals; may help trace the culprits.
key_stories.key_quote: I’m not downloading an exe file ever, no matter how legit this looks.

key_stories.title: Finding the True Bottleneck
key_stories.summary: While profiling the hack, Kaze and Sauraen realized frame-rate drops stemmed from RSP time, not the RDP.  Switching to Fast3D X3 immediately raised Course 1 to full speed, validating months of microcode work.
key_stories.challenge: Course 1 was capped at ~46 FPS despite visual simplicity.
key_stories.process: Profiled on console, compared X2 vs X3 builds, isolated RSP time.
key_stories.outcome: Adopted X3 as default and began planning further RSP-centric optimizations.
key_stories.key_quote: The bottleneck is actually the RSP and not the RDP.

key_stories.title: Redesigning Mirrors
key_stories.summary: Legacy mirror objects required per-instance hard-coding.  Kaze rewrote them to store axis, ranges and pivot in a small struct and fixed orientation bugs, enabling quick placement anywhere in the castle.
key_stories.challenge: Old mirror code was cumbersome and produced orientation errors.
key_stories.process: Created 8-byte parameter struct, adjusted scale and yaw, tested across three rooms.
key_stories.outcome: Fully functional, data-driven mirror system now in engine.
key_stories.key_quote: This is gonna be the easiest system to add new mirrors ever.
